abstract.p: Focused tests for clustering are designed to determine whether there is statistical evidence for raised incidence of some phenomenon around a prespecified location. The tests require definition of what is meant by ‘around’ the location, and this is achieved by specifying weights associated with surrounding locations. Different weight specifications will yield different levels of statistical significance, and because of the difficulty in knowing how to define the weights, it is tempting to try different definitions with the hope of finding one that is highly significant. This, however, introduces the problem of multiple testing; one will eventually be able to reject a null hypothesis if one tries often enough. This article describes approaches for adjusting the significance level when multiple tests, associated with varying definitions for the weights, are carried out. The approaches are developed for a local scan statistic, a maximum chi-square statistic, and a modified version of Stone’s statistic. An illustration is provided using leukemia data from central New York State.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Focused statistical tests are used to examine the null hypothesis of no raised incidence in a variable of interest (e.g. disease), around a prespecified geographic location of interest.1 These tests are implemented by specifying weights for surrounding locations, in such a manner to match the magnitude of the weights with the magnitude of the risk associated with the alternative hypothesis. Unfortunately, this specification is often difficult in the absence of knowledge about the potential spatial manifestation of the process.

One way forward is to ‘scan’ several different spatial scales by trying difference weight specifications. This brings the added challenge of adjusting the statistical test for the (correlated) multiple testing that occurs across scales. In particular, in the absence of adjustment, multiple testing increases the probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis by chance alone. The Bonferroni adjustment, where the nominal probability of a Type I error, α, is divided by the number of tests to determine the level of α to be used for each test, is simple to carry out. However, it is assumes that the individual tests are independent, resulting in conservative decisions (where it becomes too difficult to reject the null hypothesis) in situations where tests are correlated.

Rogerson2 and Rogerson and Kedron3 demonstrate how existing results for the statistical detection of significant temporal changepoints in sequences of normal random variables may be used to adjust the significance level associated with scanning correlated local statistics (including Getis’ Gi and the local Moran) across a number of spatial scales. This approach cannot be used to specify the weights for all focused statistics however, since some focused statistics are not well approximated by normal distributions. In this article, I show how several existing results may be used to carry out significance testing for three such focused statistics – a local spatial scan statistic, a maximum chi-square statistic4 and a modified version of Stone’s test.5

Figure 1 depicts a typical situation for case-control data. To determine whether there is an increased likelihood for cases to be located near the site of interest, a neighborhood around the site is defined. For situations where aggregated numbers of cases and controls are reported according to predefined zones, one is left with the choice of which zones to define as ‘near’ the focal site; in panel (a), only the first zone is ‘near’, while in panel (b), the first two zones are designated as ‘near’. Rather than make this choice of neighborhood definition prior to the analysis, in this article we describe how to carry out multiple tests – associated with multiple choices for the neighborhood definition – and then adjust the results appropriately for the correlated multiple tests. sec.title: 2.1 A local spatial scan statistic
sec.p: Suppose that N individual observations can be categorized as either cases or non-cases. Let p0 be the overall probability that an individual observation is a case; this can be estimated from the data as p∧0=C/N, where C is the total number of cases. Furthermore, individual observations can be attributed to geographic zones (which can result from a geographic aggregation of either subregions, or a set of point locations). Under a binomial model, the likelihood associated with the null hypothesis that all zones are characterized by the same probability that an individual is a case is proportional to (1)L0=p∧0C(1-p∧0)N-C

The spatial scan statistic6 is based on a test of this null hypothesis, against the alternative that there is a zone of raised risk, where the probability of being a case inside of the zone (p) is greater than the risk of being a case outside of the zone (q). For the alternative hypothesis that the probability of being a case is higher in zone z than it is outside of zone z, the likelihood becomes proportional to (2)L1(z)=pCz(1-p)Nz-CzqC-Cz(1-q)(N-Nz)-(C-Cz) where Nz and Cz denote the population and number of cases within zone z, and where we are usually interested in the one-sided alternative where p > q. Furthermore, p and q can be estimated by Cz/Nz and (C-Cz)/(N-Nz), respectively.

The log likelihood ratio, ln(L1(z)/L0), is assessed for all possible zones of potential raised incidence, where these zones are of different size (up to some maximum size, specified as a fraction of the total population) and possibly shape. The maximum is also taken across all possible spatial locations for the zone centers. The scan statistic is the maximum of these likelihoods across potential zones, that is, maxzln(L1(z)/L0). To assess statistical significance, this observed statistic is compared with the distribution of maximum likelihood ratios found by simulating the null hypothesis of equal probability of being a case for all locations throughout the study area.

We now define a local version of the spatial scan statistic. Assume that the geographic zone is centered at any prespecified focal location (i) in space (e.g. this might be the location of a potential environmental hazard, a regional centroid, or any other point of interest). A local statistic defined for a particular zone centered at this location is twice the likelihood ratio, 2ln(L1(zi)/L0) where the subscript i is used to emphasize that the zone is based on a single focal location, i. A single statistical test based on this local statistic has a chi-square distribution with one degree of freedom under the null hypothesis.

sec.title: 2.1.1 Distribution of the maximum local spatial scan statistic
sec.p: Here we are interested in the distribution of the maximum likelihood ratio statistic, where the maximum is taken over a set of potential zones of varying sizes defined around location i. Thus we are interested in the distribution of the statistic (3)Λ=max{j=1…m}LRj=ln(L1i(zij)/L0) where the maximum is over a set of potential zones defined around location i. More specifically, instead of examining just one definition for the neighborhood around i, suppose we examine m potential definitions. Let zij be the neighborhood around location i that consists of the first j subregions, ordered in terms of distance from i. (More generally, it should be noted that there is no need to order the subregions in terms of distance – the only requirement is that an ordering of the subregions be specified a priori). We wish to assess the statistical significance of the ‘best’ neighborhood, i.e. the one associated with a value of j that maximizes the likelihood ratio. The multiple testing (associated with examining the maximum among m likelihood ratios instead of just one) implies that one can no longer use the chi-square distribution to assess the null hypothesis.

For the more general case than that examined here, where the scanning takes places around all locations, and not just around a particular site, simulation is used to test the null hypothesis. For the more specific case of just one focal location that is examined here, the results of Worsley,7 who provided a test for a change in binomial probabilities, may be used to provide the null distribution of (3), conditional upon the total number of cases, C. Specifically (4)pr(Λ<x)=Fc(C) where (5)Fk+1(v)=∑u=akbkFk(u)hk(u,v); ak+1≤v≤bk+1 and where ak and bk are, respectively, the smallest and largest values of Cz such that LRj < x. Furthermore (6)hk(u,v)=(uNk)(v-unk+1)(vNk+1) where Nk is the total number of observations in the first k zones, and where nk is the total number of observations in zone k. To operationalize this, the iterative calculation of the F’s begins with (7)F1(v)=1; a1≤v≤b1

sec.title: 2.1.2 Illustration
sec.p: Suppose that there are K = 3 zones (the focal zone, and two other zones), and we seek to evaluate whether there is a significant changepoint in the binomial probabilities after either zone k = 1 (i.e. a contrast between the focal zone and the other two zones) or 2 (thereby contrasting the focal zone and the zone closest to it, with the zone farthest from the focal zone). Further suppose that there are a total of N = 27 observations, distributed across the three zones according to n1 = 9, n2 = 10 and n3 = 8. We will examine the scenario where there are a total of C = 10 cases distributed across the three zones. Assume that we observe c1 = 3, c2 = 5 and c3 = 2 as the number of cases in each zone. With a potential changepoint after the first zone, the proportion of observations inside the zone that are cases is 3/9 = 0.333, and outside of the zone the proportion of observations that are cases is 7/18 = 0.389. When the first two zones are aggregated, then inside of this new zone the proportion of observations that are cases is 8/19 = 0.421, and for the remainder of the study area it is 2/8 = 0.25.
We find, using (1)–(3), that Λ=max(LR1,LR2)=max(.04,.366)=0.366.

To find the p-value associated with this observed statistic, we first find a1 = 3 and b1 = 4; they are the smallest and largest numbers of cases in the first zone, respectively, that are consistent with LR1 < 0.366. Then, using (7), F1(v)=1, for v = 3 and 4. For the next iteration, a2 = 7 and b2 = 7; 7 is the only value for the number of cases that yields LR2 < 0.366 when the ‘close’ neighborhood is defined as the first two zones. sec.title: 2.2 Maximum local chi-square statistic
sec.p: Suppose that information on the location of cases and controls is available, as is information on the location of some potential focal point of interest. A breakpoint for distance is decided upon, and the observations are then divided into the categories ‘near the focal point’ and ‘far from the focal point’. This leads to a 2 × 2 table of frequencies (cases and controls constitute one dimension of the table, and near/far the other). A chi-square test for the independence of the rows and columns constitutes a test of whether cases are relatively more common ‘near’ the focal point. However, different decisions regarding the distance breakpoint can lead to different results for the 2 × 2 table of frequencies, and it is of interest to assess the statistical significance of the most significant table. Miller and Siegmund4 give results for the asymptotic null distribution of the maximal chi-square statistic across the possible 2 × 2 tables, when the variable used to decide the breakpoint (e.g. distance, in our spatial case of interest here) is continuous. Koziol8 derives the exact null distribution for the small sample case. As an aside, Hirotsu9 and Lagazio et al.10 use a global, cumulative chi-square statistic, based on the sum of the individual chi-square results for all of the 2 × 2 tables; the individual, local 2 × 2 chi-square statistics then have the desirable property of adding to this global, cumulative chi-square statistic. Here we are instead interested in the distribution of the maximum of these local statistics.

In this regard, Boulesteix11 has pointed out that Koziol’s small-sample results for the distribution of maximum chi-squares across 2 × 2 tables10 are only appropriate when the variable (e.g. distance) takes on as many values as there are observations. However, it is often the case that the discriminating variable is ordinal – for example, the binary observations (such as cases and controls) may instead be organized into say K zones arranged according to increasing ordinal distance away from a prespecified location of interest. The K × 2 table of frequencies may be consolidated into a 2 × 2 table by aggregating the first k rows into one new row, and by aggregating the last K − k rows into another new row. If we denote the usual chi-square goodness-of-fit statistic for this table χk2, the maximal chi-square statistic is max χk2, where the maximum is taken over all possible values of k = 1,2, … ,K − 1.

We now summarize the Boulesteix approach to assessing the significance of the maximal chi-square statistic for this scenario. Specifically, we seek the value of pr(maxk=1,2,…,K-1χk2≥d), where d is the observed maximal chi-square value.

Let N be the total number of observations, N1 be the total number of cases, and N2 the total number of controls (alternatively, instead of controls, one could also define these as non-cases). For the calculations that follow, it is also necessary to redefine d by first subtracting a small, arbitrary quantity; this is necessary to account for the fact that we seek the probability that the maximum chi-square statistic is greater than, or equal, to d. Thus let a = d − ε; in practice, one could take, e.g. ε = 0.001d. Define the following general functions of x (13)lowera(x)=N2xN-N1N2aNxN(1-xN)(1N1+1N2)uppera(x)=N2xN+N1N2aNxN(1-xN)(1N1+1N2)

sec.title: 2.3 The maximum difference between observed and expected proportions
sec.p: In our consideration of the null hypothesis of no raised risk around the site of interest, here we assume that the set of zones is organized in terms of decreasing risk away from the site (e.g. in terms of increasing distance), and condition on the total number of observations (C), so that the total number of observed and total number of expected cases are equal. Stone5 suggested as a local statistic the maximal observed/expected ratio among the cumulated observed and expected values. One weakness of this statistic is that large ratios can result when the expected values are small, and hence the statistic can be very sensitive to the presence of small expectations.

Here we will use the recursive approach suggested by Conover,12 to find the statistical significance (i.e. p-value) associated with the observed statistic. Let H0 = 0, and Hk=∑i=1kEi/C for k = 1,2,… , K. The first step is to find the quantities fj, for 0≤j≤C(1-d+). These are defined as fj=1-d+-j/C, if 1 − d+ − j/C corresponds to any of the values of Hk, and equal to the largest of the Hk among those smaller than 1 − d+ − j/C otherwise.

Then setting e0 = 1, find (19)ek=1-∑j=0k-1(jk)fj k-jej k≥1 continuing the recursion for all k where fk > 0. Finally the desired p-value associated with the random variable D+ is found (20)p(D+≥d+)=∑j=0[C(1-d+)](jC)fj n-jej where the square brackets indicate that the integer part of the quantity is to be taken.

For another illustration, we now consider the data considered in the two previous subsections. With 27 individuals and ten cases over the three regions, the expected number of cases in each of the three regions is equal to 3.333, 3.704 and 2.963, respectively. These are easily found by multiplying the overall incidence (10/27) by the number of individuals in each region (9, 10 and 8, respectively). The observed value of the Kolmogorov–Smirnov statistic is equal to (8−7.036)/10 = 0. 0964; this is equal to the difference between the cumulative observed and expected proportions of cases in the first two regions. The values of H are H1 = 0.333, H2 = 0.7036 and H3 = 1. This leads to values of fj = 0.736 for j = 0,1, and 2; fj = 0.333 for j = 3, 4 and 5; and all other values of f for higher values of j are equal to zero. Equation (19) yields e1 = 0.2964, e2 = 0.0879, e3 = 0.026, e4 = 0.04629 and e5 = 0.05228. The resulting p-value (equation (20)) is equal to 0.4614, and this was confirmed by simulating the null hypothesis of ten cases distributed randomly across the three regions according to the expectations mentioned above.

Note that the p-value in this case is lower than the value found in the other two subsections. Here the null process is different in the sense that the number of cases allocated to each region is not constrained by the number of individuals living in each region (n1 = 9, n2 = 10 and n3 = 8); this information is used to derive the expectations but does not act as a constraint on the counts (as it did in the two previous subsections).

sec.title: 3 Application to leukemia data from Central New York State
sec.p: Waller et al.13 analyzed the spatial patterns of observed and expected leukemia counts around eleven hazardous waste sites containing trichloroethylene. The eight-county study region was comprised of 789 census block groups containing a population of 1,057,673 million (including the cities of Syracuse and Binghamton). There were 592 cases of leukemia observed during the period 1978–1982, implying an incidence rate of about 5.6 cases per 10,000 individuals.

Here the counts were aggregated into census tracts, and the study region was defined as the ten census tracts with centroids that were closest to IBM Endicott, which is one of the eleven hazardous sites. These tracts contained 32 cases, and expected counts were derived for each tract by multiplying the tract’s proportion of study region population by 32. The maximum difference between cumulative observed and expected proportions is equal to 0.2817, and this occurs when the closest four sites are defined to be the neighborhood ‘near’ the site. In this neighborhood, 19 cases are observed and 9.98 are expected (relative risk = 1.9).

To assess the significance of the observed test statistic, the cumulative expected proportions are used to find the fj values for j ranging from 0 to 22 (as described in the text following equation (18)). When equation (19) is used to find the values of ej, and the results are used in (20), the resulting p-value is found to be p = 0.002, which is highly significant. It should be noted that a table of critical values for the Kolmogorov–Smirnov distribution yields a p-value of 0.01 for the observed test statistic, confirming that the use of such tables is unduly conservative in these situations.

sec.title: 4 Summary
sec.p: Three focused statistics are considered here, and the primary issue addressed is how to control for multiple testing when these statistics are examined using multiple choices for the associated weight matrices.

The exact tests considered here involve iteration and combinatorics. Although they are therefore easiest to implement for scenarios with small numbers of cases, it is also possible to use known relationships (e.g. for the hypergeometric distribution) to apply them in other instances as well.

The first two tests – associated with the local scan statistic and the maximum chi-square statistic – are asymptotically equivalent, and can be expected to yield similar results in most instances. These tests are based upon either a perspective of testing for independence of rows and columns when the marginal totals are fixed, or a perspective of looking for change in the binomial probability of success (i.e. an observation falling into one particular column of the table), across rows of the table, conditional upon the total number of successes. The third test discussed led to a one-sample Kolmogorov–Smirnov test based on the maximum difference between cumulative observed and expected proportions. Here the columns totals may be taken as fixed (i.e. there is a given number of cases), but row totals are no longer constrained; the sampling distribution is generated by allocating a fixed number of cases across regions according to the conditional probabilities that cases fall into particular regions.

Finally, the question of the comparative statistical power of these methods versus various alternative hypotheses has not been examined here, and this would be an interesting avenue to pursue. For instance, Worsley7 found that the likelihood methods associated with the local scan statistic had good power when the changepoint was located near the ends of the sequence (corresponding here to neighborhoods near the focal point or far from the focal point), but that other methods were slightly better when the actual change was near the middle of the series of possible changepoints.
